Award.AwardTitle: Math/Science Student Preparation and Retention Collaborative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Student Preparation and Retention Collaborative (SPARC) is providing financial and programmatic support for two cohorts of 7 to 8 high achieving, socioeconomically disadvantaged women from rural and inner city schools in Georgia through four years of a Wesleyan College undergraduate major in Biology, Chemistry, or Mathematics. The need for SPARC is great in Georgia, where there is a disparity in high school mathematics and science achievement in terms of race and socioeconomic status. The current success of the college in recruiting and retaining a diverse student body provides an ideal environment to support SPARC Scholars. Since 1836, Wesleyan College has emphasized the importance of science as well as classical learning in the education of women. This history has paid modern benefits since over seventy-six percent of natural science and mathematics graduates pursue advanced degrees or are employed in mathematics or science-related occupations. Of these graduates, twenty-five percent are women of color.

Intellectual merit: Scholarship students receive the following: integrated academic support; faculty, peer and alumnae mentoring; summer academic boot camps; and early engagement in undergraduate research are being provided. As a result of these programs, it is anticipated that eighty percent of these scholars will graduate and ninety percent of these graduates will pursue advanced study or employment in STEM fields.

Broader Impact: The project is increasing the national diversity of women who graduate with degrees in Biology, Chemistry or Mathematics, informing the design of initiatives at other, larger institutions that have adopted smaller learning communities, and encouraging retention in mathematics and science fields. Boot camps are providing models for summer undergraduate academic preparation and helping students develop enthusiasm for and confidence in the study of math and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The future of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields depends on an educated, diverse workforce that can bring creative, collaborative solutions to the multiplicity of challenges faced by our nation and the world. However, data from many sources paints a disheartening picture of the current diversity of the science and mathematics workforce in the United States. Bachelor’s degree attainment in STEM fields, particularly among African Americans, has remained stagnant (or declined) for more than a decade. Although women have made impressive strides in STEM degree attainment in the last 15 years in some fields, certain areas, such as mathematics and chemistry, have not grown proportionally. Minority women are still at-risk for poor retention in the sciences, even in fields like biology, where large increases in degree completion by women have been made.  Additionally, the enrollment of minority women in graduate programs in science, particularly in chemistry and mathematics, remains problematic. In combination with ethnicity, another substantial risk factor for failing to retain high-achieving students in STEM fields is socioeconomic status. National data indicates that students from the lowest economic quartile are least likely to complete college and to major in STEM fields. In addition, a recent study has suggested that being a female from a socioeconomically disadvantaged situation is negatively correlated with successful navigation through college and attainment of a STEM degree. This study was designed to assess the influence of multimodal programming on undergraduate STEM degree attainment by two cohorts of socioeconomically disadvantaged, but academically high achieving women. 

At the undergraduate level, graduating more diverse STEM majors requires novel, intentional programming which is aimed at addressing the financial, academic and social barriers to STEM degree completion experienced by underrepresented populations. In 2011, our institution, a small, liberal arts, single sex College, began a program designed to test the hypothesis that increased financial support, intensive faculty advising, novel networking opportunities, major-specific upperclass student peer mentoring and academic "Bootcamp" experiences would have a positive impact on at-risk student academic performance and retention in STEM majors. The participants chosen for this initiative (SPARC Scholars) were two small cohorts of diverse (54% minority), academically high achieving but socioeconomically disadvantaged (74% fully Pell-eligible, with $0 Expected Family Contribution) women from the state of Georgia, intending to major in STEM fields. To assess the success of the programming, SPARC Scholar performance was compared to another set of students, the Match group. These students were chosen to parallel SPARC Scholars in terms of their diversity, socioeconomic status, high academic achievement and intended majors; they did not participate in SPARC programming, but were offered existing institutional financial, academic and social support.

Assessment of the impact of week-long summer academic Bootcamp experiences indicated marked effects on SPARC Scholar cohort cohesiveness (Bootcamp I) and statistically significant increases in SPARC Scholar dynamic spatial reasoning abilities (Bootcamp II). Self-reported data indicated that SPARC Scholars viewed their Bootcamp and faculty advising experiences favorably and that upper class majors serving as Peer Advisors had a positive impact on Scholars' overall academic experience. The data further indicated that SPARC programming was successful in supporting significantly better undergraduate academic success in STEM majors, as measured by GPA at graduation (SPARC Scholars average GPA was 3.33+.43 versus the Match average GPA of 2.91+.45), although retention to graduation in STEM majors was not significantly different between the two groups (SPARC Scholar retention was 52% and the Match retention was 56%). SPARC Scholars chose to major in a greater diversity of STEM fields than the Match (for instance, no students in the Match majored in Chemistry, but 17% of SPARC Scholars did).

SPARC Scholars also demonstrated postgraduate outcomes that were more STEM-related than the Match population. Figure 1 indicates that more SPARC Scholars (blue bars) than the Match population (orange bars) enrolled in Graduate/Professional schools related to their major or were employed in major-related fields within two years of graduation. Overall, SPARC Scholars achieved major-related outcomes in much higher percentages than the Match (73% for SPARC Scholars versus 22% for the Match). 

Broader Impact

The inclusion of diverse populations is essential to the progression of STEM fields and must be encouraged at all levels in the human resource pipeline. Our findings suggest that a combination of financial and programmatic investment in socioeconomically disadvantaged, high achieving women supported their academic success in STEM majors and produced significantly more students who pursued STEM-related postgraduate outcomes. Particular elements of this programming, including peer mentoring, intensive faculty advising, spatial reasoning training, cohort building initiatives and intentional networking opportunities can be replicated at other, larger institutions to encourage the success of similar populations of students.
